title-group.article-title: Assessment of Annual Effective Dose Due to the Indoor Radon Exposure in Districts Bagh and Kahuta of the Azad Kashmir, Pakistan

article-meta.aff: aDepartment of Physics, University of Azad Jammu & Kashmir, Muzaffarbad 13100, Azad Kashmir, Pakistan
bPhysics Division, PINSTECH, P.O. Nilore, Islamabad, Pakistan

author-notes.corresp: M. Rafique, Department of Physics, University of Azad Jammu & Kashmir, Muzaffarabad 13100, Azad Kashmir, Pakistan. Tel. 923009189301, Fax (+92)5822-960402, E-Mail mrafique@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-holder: International Society of the Built Environment

abstract.p: In continuation to our earlier studies concerning generation of the baseline indoor radon data, an indoor radon measurement survey was carried out in the districts Bagh and Kahuta, state of the Azad Jammu and Kashmir. In this context, 150 houses were selected in the aforesaid districts and CN-85-based box-type radon detectors installed in bedroom and living room of each house. The detectors were exposed to indoor radon for 3 months. After etching CN-85 detectors in 6 M NaOH at 70°C for 3 h, the observed track densities were related to the indoor radon concentration using calibration factor of 0.0092 tracks cm−2·h−1 per Bq·m−3. The measured indoor radon concentration ranged from 56 to 124 Bq·m−3 and 61 to 106 Bq·m−3 in the studied areas of districts Bagh and Kahuta, respectively. The mean annual effective dose ranged from 1.42 ± 0.15 to 3.12 ± 0.10 mSv·y−1 with an average of 2.16 ± 0.13 mSv·y−1 in the district Bagh and 1.54 ± 0.14 to 2.68 ± 0.12 mSv·y−1 with an average of 2.17 ± 0.13 mSv·y−1 in the district Kahuta. These values are within the safe limits recommended by the World Heath Organization.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Radon is a noble gas and is produced as a part of the normal radioactive decay chain of uranium. Uranium has been around us ever since the creation of earth. Its most abundant isotope (i.e. 238U) has a very long half-life of 4.5 billion years. Uranium, radium and thus radon will continue to be generated for millions of years at about the same concentrations as they do now. The fact that radon is a noble gas ensures that it is not immobilised by chemically reacting within the medium. Consequently, radon diminishes only by radioactive decay as it moves from its source. Its radioactivity and relatively longer half-life of 3.82 days make it useful in physical sciences as a natural tracer and allow it to be measured with a remarkable sensitivity. For humans, the prominent effect of radon is that higher concentrations result in severe health hazard leading to occurrence of lung cancer [1,2]. Lung cancer has been reported to be the leading cause of cancer death for both men and women in the US population [3]. Although the majority of these lung cancer deaths are attributable to cigarette smoking, lung cancer risk projections, extrapolated from case–control epidemiological studies of radon-exposed underground miners, attributed to a considerable number of lung cancer deaths per year in the US population due to residential radon exposure [4]. Therefore, radon measurements play a critical role in monitoring human health and safety in homes. Indoor radon and its short-lived daughter products are known to contribute the largest fraction to the dose received by the general public from natural background radiation. The average worldwide annual effective dose equivalent from natural sources of radiation, in normal background areas, was estimated to be 2.4 mSv of which 1.275 mSv could be contributed by the indoor radon [5]. That is why a large number of groups throughout the world are engaged in the measurements of radon and its short-lived daughters on national levels [6–22]. In this regard, limited work has been done in the state of Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK). Therefore, systematic studies have been initiated to measure indoor radon throughout the AJK. This article reports the measurement of indoor radon concentration in the districts of Bagh and Kahuta with an objective to generate and set an indoor radon baseline data for the state of the AJK. Surveys of indoor radon concentrations and assessment of cancer risks due to exposure in other districts have already been reported [13–17].

sec.title: Geology of the Studied Area
sec.p:
The Bagh and Kahuta are amongst the main districts of the AJK covering an area of 1368 km2. In general, the geology and stratography of the Kahuta and Bagh areas are of geological interest because igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks are well exposed and juxtaposed together. These rocks form a part of the Hazara–Kashmir syntaxis. The rocks around syntaxial bend are folded and faulted extensively forming imbricate and nappe blocks. In the Kahuta area, a Palaeozoic unconformity occurs between Dogra slates and rocks of the Gondwana group. The Muzaffarabad district is marked by the absence of a large part of the rocks from Palaeozoic to Mesozoic as it was uplifted and exposed during Palaeozoic and Mesozoic times as is indicated by the occurrence of bauxite/lalerite of the Palaeocenc age on top of the Cambrian Abbottabad formation [23]. The geographical map of the studied area is shown in Figure 1. Fig. 1
Map of the AJK showing the sampling points in the Bagh and Kahuta districts.

Topographically, the entire Bagh district is mountainous area, generally sloping from northeast to southwest. The area falls in lesser Himalayas zone. The main range in district is Pir Panjal. The Haji Pir Pass is situated at the height of 3421 m above sea level. The general elevation is between 1500 and 2500 m above sea level. Mountains are generally covered with coniferous forests. Mahl Nala in Bagh sub-division and Betar Nala in Haveli sub-division are the two main streams.

However, other numerous rivulets also flow within the district. Climate of the district varies with altitude. The temperature generally remains between 2°C and 40°C. The main eastern part of the district is very cold in the winter and moderate in summer. However, in the lower valleys, the localities bordering Bagh at Kohala and its adjoining areas (Mongbajri and Arja-Bagh) remain cold in winter and hot in summer. May, June and July are the hottest months. Maximum and minimum temperatures during the month of June are about 40°C and 22°C, respectively. December, January and February are the coldest months. The maximum temperature in January is about 16°C and minimum temperature is 3°C. The annual precipitation is about 1500 mm [24].

sec.title: Selection of Sampling Sites
sec.p: For the present indoor radon measurement survey, 150 houses were carefully selected in the districts of Bagh (85 houses) and Kahuta (65 houses). As mentioned earlier, these districts lie on the geological fault line. The choice of houses was based on our convenience, willingness of the dwellers and their location within the studied area. CN-85 detectors were installed in bedroom and drawing room of each house. The selected sites lie within a radius of about 30 km. These sites included Gujar Kohala, Chaman kot, Chamaiti, Chiralla, Dhirkot, Rangla, Mallot, Jaglari, Birpani, Bani Pasari, Ravali, Bagh city, Chitra Topi, Bhount Bhaiar, Rehra and Nar Sher Ali Khan in the Bagh district and Bhudal, Bhedi, Kullal, Kahuta city, Degwar Tirwan, Chanjal, Kailar, Kala mula, Sangali in the Kahuta district. Unfortunately, due to the mishandling of dwellers, detectors could not be retrieved from 30 houses.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Large sheets of CN-85 detectors were cut into small strips and placed in a box-type holder having dimensions 3 × 3 × 1.14 cm3. Two detector strips were placed at two opposite walls of the holder. The design of this type of radon detector ensures that all the aerosols and radon decay products are kept outside and only radon diffuses into the sensitive volume of the chamber. Selection of the sampling sites for detector installation was based on their geographical spread, locality and willingness of the dwellers. These CN-85-based detectors were then installed at heights (i.e. about 1.5 m from the ground) in bedroom and drawing room of 150 selected houses of districts Bagh and Kahuta. After 90 days (i.e. September to December, 2009), the indoor radon was collected. The retrieved CN-85 detectors were etched in 6 M NaOH at 70°C for 3 h. Then, the detectors were first washed under running water and then in an ultrasonic cleaner bath. After counting under an optical microscope, track densities were corrected for background correction and then related to the radon concentrations using a calibration factor of 0.0092 tracks cm−2·h−1 = 1 Bq·m−3. Finally, average annual effective dose (H) (mSv·y−1) expected to be received by the inhabitants of the studied area due to the indoor radon and its progeny was calculated using UNSCEAR model [5].

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p:
The observed indoor radon concentration values in the bedroom and drawing room were averaged for each of the houses of the studied area. The results obtained are given in Tables 1 and 2 for the studied towns of the districts of Bagh and Kahuta, respectively. As seen in Table 1, weighted average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼56 ± 6.08 to 124 ± 4.06 Bq·m−3 for the houses of the district Bagh. The minimum value of weighted average radon concentration was recorded in the Gujjar Kohala region, whereas the maximum value was found in the Chitra Topi. Table 1.
Indoor radon concentration and the annual mean effective dose calculated in the region of Bagh district of AJK

Indoor radon concentrations and the annual mean effective dose calculated in the region of Kahuta district of AJK

Average values of radon concentration and resulting doses 85.80 ± 5.09 2.16 ± 0.13

The weighted average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼61 ± 5.55 to 106 ± 4.61 Bq·m−3 for the houses surveyed in the district Kahuta. The minimum value was recorded in the Kailar region, whereas the maximum value was found in the Kahuta city.

From the survey results given in Tables 1 and 2, it is clear that all the houses of the studied districts have indoor radon concentration above 56 Bq·m−3 and below 124 Bq·m−3. The larger variation in the indoor radon concentration in the houses surveyed could be due to the different living styles of the inhabitants, ventilation systems, variation in geology, etc. Moreover, the houses having higher values of the weighted average indoor radon concentration could be due to the fractures and cracks produced underneath the houses by the 8 October 2005 Kashmir earthquake, and also might be due to poor ventilation system. All these factors could contribute towards the increase in indoor radon concentrations in the studied dwellings.

Figure 2 shows frequency distribution of the weighted average indoor radon concentrations in the houses surveyed (both in Bagh and Kahuta districts). Variations in the indoor radon levels are shown in Figure 2. Graph follows lognormal distribution as predicted and reported in many previous studies [15,18]. Fig. 2
Frequency distribution of indoor radon concentration in districts Bagh and Kahuta.

sec.title: Determination of Effective Dose from Radon Exposure
sec.p: For the estimation of average annual effective dose, H (mSv·y−1) received by the inhabitants of the studied area due to the indoor radon and its progeny, Equation (1) was used for the calculation as was given by UNSCEAR [5].

H = C × F × O × T × D(1) where C stands for weighted average radon concentration in Bq·m−3, F (0.4, taken for indoor inhabitants) for equilibrium equivalent concentration factor, O for occupancy factor (0.8 as taken in UNSCEAR 2000 report), T for time (8760 h·y−1) and D for dose conversion factor (9 nSv·h−1 per Bq·m−3).

For the regions of districts of Bagh (Table 1), the mean annual effective doses due to the indoor radon ranged from 1.42 ± 0.15 to 3.12 ± 0.10 mSv·y−1. The minimum dose due to the indoor radon (1.42 ± 0.15 mSv·y−1) was noted in Gujar Kohala region, whilst the maximum value of the dose (3.12 ± 0.10 mSv·y−1) was found in the Chitra Topi area.

Table 2 shows mean annual effective doses due to the indoor radon in the district Kahuta. As seen in this table, the mean annual effective dose ranged from 1.54 ± 0.14 to 2.68 ± 0.12 mSv·y−1. The minimum dose due to the indoor radon (1.54 ± 0.14 mSv·y−1) was noted in the Kailar region, whilst the maximum value of the dose (2.68 mSv·y−1) was found in the Kahuta city.

In Table 3, the results obtained from this study are compared with the data published for other parts of the world. The current values of the indoor radon concentrations are comparable with the values reported for other districts of AJK as well as for several parts of Pakistan. Comparing with the data reported for UK, USA, Turkey (Azmir, Istanbul) and India (Himachal Pradesh and Assam), the current values are on the higher side, whereas the current values are lower than those reported for India (Meghalaya), Ireland, China, Kenya, Sweden, etc. Table 3.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, in order to map out the state of AJK concerning the generation of baseline data for indoor radon, measurements were performed in two districts namely Bagh and Kahuta. From the measured indoor radon concentration, the mean annual effective doses were calculated. The weighted average indoor radon concentration in dwellings of Bagh and Kahuta districts, ranged from 56 to124 Bq·m−3, whilst resulting indoor radon doses ranged from 1.42 to 3.12 mSv·y−1. According to the recommendations made by the Health Protection Agency, UK (200 Bq·m−3) and US EPA (148 Bq·m−3), all the houses surveyed are within the safe limits.
